Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residence requirement
Legal_Issue: Whether the appellants met the residence requirements under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Appellants were absent from Canada for 1,112 days and present for only 111 days in the four years preceding application
Mode of living remained centralized in Hong Kong
Leased an apartment and schooled child in Hong Kong
Court_Ruling: Appellants did not meet the residence requirements for Canadian citizenship
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged compliance with residence requirement; delayed notification creating legitimate expectation
Legal_Standard: Physical presence in Canada for at least 1,095 days in the four years before application
Assessment_Factor: Duration of physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Delayed notification and its impact on procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Records of entry and exit from Canada
School enrollment records of child in Hong Kong
Relief_Sought: Successful appeal and approval of citizenship application
Governing_Rule: Applicants must be physically present in Canada for at least 1,095 days in the four years preceding application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of physical presence in Canada
Harm_Assessment: No harm recognized; failure to meet statutory requirement
Cause_Description: Appellants' application for citizenship was denied due to insufficient physical presence in Canada
Evidence_Handling: Court reviewed documentary evidence on residency and lifestyle
Evidence_Issues: Lack of evidence demonstrating compliance with residency requirement
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence showed predominant residency in Hong Kong
Decision_Rationale: Appellants failed to meet the 1,095-day physical presence requirement; no substantive rights arose from delayed notification
Evidentiary_Issues: Absence of credible evidence showing physical presence in Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective assessment of physical presence under s. 5(1)(c)
